cards.title: What are your top tips to survive a heatwave?
cards.rawTitle: What are your top tips to survive a heatwave?

item.title: What are your top tips to survive a heatwave?
item.trailText: On Wednesday the UK is expecting a heatwave, but in many parts of the world hot weather is normal. If you live in a country where high temperatures are a daily occurence, we’d like to hear your tips
item.standFirst: On Wednesday the UK is expecting a heatwave, but in many parts of the world hot weather is normal. If you live in a country where high temperatures are a daily occurence, we’d like to hear your tips
item.body:
On Wednesday temperatures in the UK are expected to soar. Though this is unusual for those living in Britain – for many people in the world, hot weather is part of everyday life. So we’d like to find out the best ways to survive the heat?

If you happen to live, or have lived, in a hot country - whether that’s in Asia, Africa, or the Americas, we’d like to hear your tips. And if you’re in the UK, show us your photos of how you’re coping in the heatwave.

We’ll use the best contributions in our reporting.

You can share your tips and photos by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments.’

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site

cards.title: London exodus / Have you moved out?

item.title: Have you moved out of London? Share your experiences
item.trailText: With house prices and rents spiralling many have made the decision to leave the capital. We’d like to hear from people who’ve made the move. Share your experiences via GuardianWitness
item.standFirst: With house prices and rents spiralling many have made the decision to leave the capital. We’d like to hear from people who’ve made the move. Share your experiences via GuardianWitness
item.body:
“When a man is tired of London, he is tired of life,” said Samuel Johnson. Now many of the city’s residents disagree, fleeing London to get a life. The reasons are often financial, but can also be a desire for a change of pace or new experiences. It could even be the policies of another Johnson.

We’d like to hear from people who’ve left the capital – whether that’s to another city, the countryside or even abroad. And also from those who are welcoming them (or not).

What’s it really like when you leave? Has the move been everything you’ve hoped for – or have there been unexpected downsides? We’d like to hear about your experiences – both the good and the bad. What do you miss most about London living and what are the benefits of where you live now?

Share your stories – and photos and do let us know where you’ve moved to and your reasons for leaving London. We’ll publish the most interesting responses on the Guardian site.

You can share your photos, videos and stories by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments.’

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.

headerImage.caption: Moving house day Photograph: Paul Clowney/Alamy

cards.title: 'Leap second' / How are you planning to spend it?
cards.rawTitle: How are you planning to spend it?

item.title: 'Leap second': how are you planning to spend it?
item.trailText: Just before midnight tonight the earth gains an extra second, as atomic clocks recalibrate with the turning of the earth. How will you take advantage of it?
item.standFirst: Just before midnight tonight the earth gains an extra second, as atomic clocks recalibrate with the turning of the earth. How will you take advantage of it?
item.body:
Each moment of human existence is precious, and we’ll all be getting an extra one at midnight on Tuesday (GMT). The “leap second” is to allow extremely precise devices to keep in sync with the Earth’s rotation, which is gradually slowing. The extra second added by atomic clocks at 23:59:60 will keep official time in tune with when night and day are supposed to happen.

A second can be an age: time enough to fall in love, spot a shooting star, or click ‘send’ on a massively misguided email.

We want to know how you’re going to spend yours. Here are a few suggestions from Twitter:


Please do add your own suggestions below the line (that is, if you intend to be awake). We’ll add our favourites to the article.

cards.title: Guardian first book award / Add your nominations

item.title: Add your nominations for the Guardian first book award 2015
item.trailText: One of the titles on the longlist for this year’s prize for literary debuts is up to readers. Please make your nominations below
item.standFirst: One of the titles on the longlist for this year’s prize for literary debuts is up to readers. Please make your nominations below
item.body:
The shelves are full to bursting, the judges hunched in concentration as they pore over submissions for the 2015 Guardian first book award. They’re looking to fill nine slots on this year’s longlist, to be announced in mid-August. But for the tenth, it’s over to you - and here’s your chance to tell us about the new voices we may have missed, the debuts so dynamic they demand to be in contention for the 2015 prize.

Last year the readers’ selection was May-Lan Tan’s unsettling collection of short stories, Things to Make and Break, with the Anglo-Breton poet Claire Trévien’s The Shipwrecked House being chosen the year before. These follow poetry from Sarah Jackson and the inaugural readers’ choice, Juan Pablo Villalobos’s novel Down the Rabbit Hole.

As that eclectic list suggests, we’re looking for first books in any form: poetry or polemic, memoir or mystery story. Recent winners of the award include a study of music in the 20th century, a biography of cancer and last year’s winner, Colin Barrett’s lyrical evocation of life in small-town Ireland, Young Skins.

To be considered for the award, books chosen must be published in the UK between 1 January 2015 and 31 December 2015, for the main judging panel, and 1 September 2014 and 31 August 2015 for the readers’ selection – and they must be published in print. They also have to be the author’s first book to be published in English anywhere in the world. Translations must have appeared within five years of publication in the original language. Check out the terms and conditions for further details.

We have nominations from publishers galore already, so we’d like to hear from readers who can help us find writers working off the beaten track, and imprints that are only starting to make an impression. As always, we’re particularly interested to hear about voices or opinions that struggle to make themselves heard above the babble of the 180,000 titles published every year in the UK.

To make a nomination, just post the title and author of your choice in the thread below before midnight on 12 July, as well as a paragraph or two explaining why this book should win the Guardian first book award. A little information about the publisher would also help us track them down.

That’s all we need to start looking for this year’s most unexpected debuts – so what are you waiting for?

cards.title: Migration / Tell us your stories about migrating from a developing country
cards.rawTitle: Tell us your stories about migrating from a developing country

item.title: Migration: tell us your stories and help us put the spotlight back on people
item.trailText: Have you migrated from a developing country? Do you live in a community where migrants are being hosted? Tell us about your experiences and help us put people rather than politics at the centre of the migration story
item.standFirst: Have you migrated from a developing country? Do you live in a community where migrants are being hosted? Tell us about your experiences and help us put people rather than politics at the centre of the migration story
item.body:
As migrant crises in the Mediterranean and south-east Asia continue, governments and refugee agencies are struggling to find a solution. But beyond global policy discussions lies the stories of migrants themselves.

If you’ve made a journey as a migrant from a developing country, or are considering embarking on one, we’d like to know why. What has motivated or forced you to leave your country? What other options, if any, were available to you?

If you have already made the journey, how was it arranged? What were the travelling conditions like, and how long did it take?

We’d also like to hear from people living in communities where new arrivals are being hosted. Where are people coming from and what kind of support are they receiving? What’s the mood on migration where you live?

You can share your photos, videos and stories by clicking on the blue “Add your contribution” button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for “GuardianWitness assignments”.

If you, prefer you can fill in the form below. You don’t need to supply your real name, but please do leave contact details if you’re happy for us to get in touch. You can also email us at development@theguardian.com.

And if you are on Twitter, you can share your experiences with us using the hashtag #whymigrate.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed before publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.

cards.title: Wimbledon 2015 / How are you experiencing it?

item.title: Wimbledon 2015: how are you experiencing it?
item.trailText: Whether camping and queueing for tickets, or watching the action overseas, share your Wimbledon experiences with us
item.standFirst: Whether camping and queueing for tickets, or watching the action overseas, share your Wimbledon experiences with us
item.body:
Since Wimbledon is one of very few major sporting events where tickets are still available on the day of play, we’d like to hear from anyone who is camping in Wimbledon Park during the tournament, and joining the daily queues in the hope of securing those all important Centre Court tickets.

If you do not plan on pitching up your tent at Wimbledon, we’d like to know how you are planning on enjoying the tournament. Has your garden been transformed into a centre court for you to watch every game, set and match with strawberries and cream? Or will you be holed up in a dark room for two weeks with the air conditioning on? You might be a huge Wimbledon fan currently living overseas, having to burn the midnight oil to get a chance to see your favourite players in action. Wherever you are in the world, we’d like to see your Wimbledon photos and experiences. We’ll feature the best of them on our site.

You can share your Wimbledon pictures, videos and stories by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’ – and if you add it to the homepage – you can keep up with all our assignments.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.

cards.title: Welfare / Share your experiences of receiving child and working tax credits
cards.rawTitle: Share your experiences of receiving child and working tax credits

item.title: Are you receiving child and working tax credits? Share your experiences
item.trailText: Child and working tax credits look increasingly likely to be targeted by the government when cutting the welfare bill. How will this affect your finances?
item.standFirst: Child and working tax credits look increasingly likely to be targeted by the government when cutting the welfare bill. How will this affect your finances?
item.body:
Ahead of the budget on July 8, child tax credits and working tax credits look likely to be targeted by the government as part of its mission to cut the welfare bill. We’d like to hear from anyone currently receiving either what the likely effect any cuts would have on their finances.

We are particularly interested in hearing from anyone in the constituency of Blackburn with Darwen, though we do want to hear from you if you live elsewhere in the UK. Share your experiences and we’ll hopefully use your most interesting responses in our reporting

Please use the form below to submit your response - it won’t be visible on the site. You don’t need to supply your real name, but please do leave contact details if you’re happy for us to get in touch. You can also email us at guardian.witness@theguardian.com

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.
